title: Diploma in Financial Accounting
headline: The free online course on the streams of accounting, preparing financial statements and the structure of balance sheet.
description: The free online course on financial accounting teaches you about the streams of accounting, as well as the concept of financial statements and the basic structure of a balance sheet. You will learn about the components of a profit and loss account, as well as the concept of conservatism and depreciation. You will also be able to explain the concept of ratio analysis. Start this course today to improve your understanding of financial accounting.
courseDescription:
Financial accounting is a free online course that begins by introducing you to the streams of accounting, as well as the concept of financial statements and the basic structure of a balance sheet. The course will also introduce you to the major components of a profit and loss account, as well as the concept of conservatism and depreciation. Cash flow statement as the summary of cash flows (receipts and payments) during an accounting period will also be covered in this course.

The course then explains corporate governance as a collection of mechanisms, processes and relationships by which a company is controlled and managed. You will learn about the main principles of corporate governance, as well as how Enron failed using proper corporate governance. This course will teach you about accounting standards and principles, as well as the evolution of accounting and how to record financial transactions.

Furthermore, this course will help you get familiar with the interpretation and analysis of financial statements, as well as introduce you to the concept of ratio analysis. You will learn about the ratio and financial statement analysis for TCS. This free online course will be of great interest to students, researchers, and anyone with an interest in financial accounting and preparing financial statements. So, register for this course and start your next learning journey today.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

    • Differentiate between the three streams of accounting.
    • Explain the purpose of financial statements.
    • Analyze the basic business model.
    • Explain the purpose of a balance sheet.
    • List the items under liabilities and assets.
    • List the three different types of assets. 
    • Outline the two types of fixed assets.
    • Explain the difference between tangible and intangible assets.
    • Outline the equation for assets and owners fund.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Financial accounting deals with recording of financial transactions and preparation of financial statements 
    • Management accounting often refers to managerial accounting which gives you information on decision making and it is mainly for internal users.
    • Cost Accounting deals with recording of costs, analysis of costs, and preparation of cost statements. It is mainly targeted to internal users.
    • A balance sheet shows the cumulative position of resources (assets) and sources of funds (liabilities) at the end of the year.
    • The profit and loss account shows ‘revenues and costs’ performance during the quarter of a year.
    • The annual report usually contains information such as financial statements, the chairman's statement, the board of director’s & committees, auditors report, and directors report.
    • Financial statements are records that provide information about an individual’s, organization’s, or business’ financial status.
    • Three important financial statements are balance sheet, profit and loss, and cash flow statement.
    • A balance sheet or statement of financial position is a summary of the financial balances of an entity on a particular date.
    • The elements of a balance sheet have three main parts: assets, liabilities, and owners fund.

  • Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • List the elements of the profit and loss account.
    • Outline the equation for calculating profit and loss.
    • List the six categories of expenses in a profit and loss account.
    • Explain the importance of a matching concept.
    • Explain the concept of conservatism.
    • List the three qualitative characteristics of conservatism.
    • List the causes of the depreciation of fixed assets.
    • List the four methods of providing depreciation.
    • Describe what is meant by inventory valuation.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Profit and loss account discloses the result of the working of an entity during the period/accounting year.
    • The major components of a profit and loss account are income and expenses.
    • To calculate profit and loss, the following equation is used: Income - Expenses = P&L.
    • The profit and loss account has a list of all incomes and all expenses.
    • The six categories of expenses in a profit and loss account are the cost of materials, purchases of stock-in-trade, changes in inventories of finished goods, employee benefit expenses, finance cost, and depreciation.
    • The matching concept allows expenses to be recognized in the same accounting period when the related revenues are recognized.
    • Conservatism states that the accountant should not anticipate income and should provide for all possible losses.
    • The tree qualitative characteristics of conservatism are prudence, neutrality, and faithful representation of alternative values.
    • Depreciation is the decrease in value of fixed assets.
    • Causes of depreciation include lapse of time, wear and tear, obsolescence of technology and exhaustion.
    • The four methods of providing depreciation are the straight-line method, reducing balance method, machine hour method, and production units method.

    • Identify the different categories of cash flow statement.
    • List the three different types of cash flow statements.
    • Explain what the direct method involves operating activities.
    • Outline the process of preparing a cash flow statement.
    • Explain the importance of a cash flow statement to investors.

  • Lesson Summary 
    • A Cash flow statement was developed because there wasn’t a statement available that showed actual cash coming in and how the cash is being utilized.
    • Cash flow statement is the summary of cash flows (receipts and payments) during an accounting period. 
    • Types of cash flows include operating cash flow, investing cash flow, and financing cash flow. 
    • Operating involves day to day activities, investing involves purchasing land and financing involves taking a loan.
    • Cash flow statement is important to investors because it shows how much actual cash a company has generated within a given period of time.
    • The direct method involves actual cash inflows and outflows from the company's operations. 
    • Non-cash transactions should be excluded from the cash flows statement and should be disclosed in the financial statements.
    • In a cash flow statement, depreciation is added instead of deducted.
    • If a company wants to grow, it has to continuously make investments in new equipment, new software, and new technology.
    • Negative cash flows of investment activities is a positive thing for a company because it means that the company is investing for the further to generate more profit and cash flows.
  • Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Describe the meaning of the term corporate governance.
    • Analyze the purpose of having corporate governance.
    • List the main principles of corporate governance.
    • Describe how a corporation is structured.
    • Identify the issues that may arise in Corporate Governance.
    • Discuss the advantage of market corporate control.
    • Identify the three types of corporate governance global models.
    • Describe the reasons why Enron became bankrupt in 2001.
    • Identify the suggested reforms for accounting and corporate governance after the Enron scandal.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Corporate governance is the collection of mechanisms, processes and relationships by which a company is controlled and managed.
    • Governance structures and principles identify the distribution of rights and responsibilities among different stakeholders in the company. It includes the rules and procedures for making decisions in corporate affairs.
    • Corporate governance practices are attempts to align the interests of stakeholders.
    • The main principles of corporate governance are Transparency, Accountability, Trusteeship and Ethics.
    • Senior managers seek maximum remuneration and significant discretion.
    • Controlling owner is often a long term owner who has financial strength.
    • The Board of Directors is the legal body that is responsible for the governance of the corporation.
    • The CEO and team are the implementing body of the company’s strategic and operational decisions. 
    • The Annual Shareholder Meeting reviews the conduct of the Board and the management team.
    • Issues in corporate governance include lack of diversity, separation of chairperson and CEO, independence of auditors, and rotation of auditors.
    • Market corporate control is the market for voting shares, which give ultimate control. It prevents managers from pursuing unethical objectives.
